auto_merge.commit_message:
e.g. functions, classes, cdef classes. This should make Python access to
them perform a little better from multiple threads (since the different
threads won't be twiddling the reference counts as much) at the cost of
meaning this objects can only be deallocated in a GC pass. Since we
don't really expect these objects to be deallocated that's probably a
price worth paying.

It's only likely to improve access from Python though, and should make
no difference to access from Cython currently.
auto_merge.commit_title: Enable deferred reference counting on long-lived global objects (#7114)

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
e.g. functions, classes, cdef classes. This should make Python access to them perform a little better from multiple threads (since the different threads won't be twiddling the reference counts as much) at the cost of meaning this objects can only be deallocated in a GC pass. Since we don't really expect these objects to be deallocated that's probably a price worth paying.

It's only likely to improve access from Python though, and should make no difference to access from Cython currently.

comment_data.body: I wouldn't mind moving this into the code writer, next to the refcounting methods. The change in `Nodes.py` could probably just use the same conditions, just to keep it simple and consistent.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -10052,6 +10052,14 @@ def generate_result_code(self, code):
                 self.allow_py2_metaclass,
                 code.error_goto_if_null(self.result(), self.pos)))
         self.generate_gotref(code)
+        if (code.funcstate.scope.is_module_scope or
+                code.funcstate.scope.is_c_class_scope or
+                code.funcstate.scope.is_py_class_scope):
+            # Deferred reference counting is probably only worthwhile on global classes
+            # that we expect to be long-term accessible. 
+            code.putln("#if CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_CPYTHON && PY_VERSION_HEX >= 0x030E0000")
+            code.putln(f"PyUnstable_Object_EnableDeferredRefcount({self.result()});")
+            code.putln("#endif")

comment_data.body: Moved. I don't really expect to add much beyond these three things though

                 self.allow_py2_metaclass,
                 code.error_goto_if_null(self.result(), self.pos)))
         self.generate_gotref(code)
+        if (code.funcstate.scope.is_module_scope or
+                code.funcstate.scope.is_c_class_scope or
+                code.funcstate.scope.is_py_class_scope):
+            # Deferred reference counting is probably only worthwhile on global classes
+            # that we expect to be long-term accessible. 
+            code.putln("#if CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_CPYTHON && PY_VERSION_HEX >= 0x030E0000")
+            code.putln(f"PyUnstable_Object_EnableDeferredRefcount({self.result()});")
+            code.putln("#endif")

commit.message:
Enable deferred reference counting on long-lived global objects

e.g. functions, classes, cdef classes. This should make Python
access to them perform a little better from multiple threads
(since the different threads won't be twiddling the reference
counts as much) at the cost of meaning this objects can only
be deallocated in a GC pass. Since we don't really expect these
objects to be deallocated that's probably a price worth paying.

It's only likely to improve access from Python though, and should
make no difference to access from Cython currently.

milestone.description: First feature release after the cleanup releases 3.0 and 3.1.

title: Enable deferred reference counting on long-lived global objects
